reviewText:
Republic Pictures present "SONG OF NEVADA" (5 August 1944) (75 mins/B&W) (Fully Restored/Dolby Digitally Remastered) --- Roy Rogers (born Leonard Slye) moved to California in 1930, at the age of 18 --- played in such musical groups as The Hollywood Hillbillies, Rocky Mountaineers, Texas Outlaws and his own group, the International Cowboys --- In 1934 he formed a group with Bob Nolan and Tim Spencer called "Sons of the Pioneers" --- While in that group he was known as Leonard Slye, then Dick Weston and finally Roy Rogers --- Their songs included "Cool Water" and "Tumbling Tumbleweeds" --- They first appeared in the western "Rhythm on the Range" (1936), starring Bing Crosby --- In 1937 Roy went solo and made his first starring film in 1938, "Under Western Stars" (1938) --- He made almost 100 films --- then came television, "The Roy Rogers Show" (1951) ran on CBS from October 1951 through September 1964.

Under Joseph Kane (Director), Harry Grey (Producer), Olive Cooper (Screenwriter), Gordon Kahn (Screenwriter), Jack A. Marta (Cinematographer), Fred A. Ritter (Musical Direction/Supervision), Morton Scott (Composer (Music Score), Tony Martinelli (Editor), Larry Ceballos (Choreography) - - - - Our story line and plot, A western millionaire ranch owner pretends to be dead to fool his daughter who he wants to cure of her eastern uppity ways --- He hires Roy to convince her to return to her western roots and not marry a pantywaist big city dude --- After directing the first forty-two Roy Rogers Westerns, Joseph Kane leaves the series --- Roy and Dale were not husband and wife when they co-starred in this oater, but the chemistry is very much in place --- the theme is very much like "The Taming of the Shrew", but this time it's surrounded by sagebrush --- very much the musical extravaganza during the Republic Years for B-Westerns --- some wonderful tunes, IT'S LOVE LOVE LOVE -- NEW MOON OVER NEVADA -- HI HO LITTLE DOGGIES -- WHAT ARE WE GOIN' TO DO? -- HARUM SCARUM BARON OF THE HARMONIUM -- A COWBOY HAS TO YODEL IN THE MORNING -- SONG OF NEVADA -- LITTLE JOE THE WRANGLER -- HOME ON THE RANGE -- WHAT ARE WE GONNA DO ABOUT THIS RAINY DAY? -- THE WIGWAM SONG -- SWEET BETSY FROM PIKE -- AND HER GOLDEN HAIR WAS HANGING DOWN HER BACK

BIOS:
1. Roy Rogers (aka: Leonard Franklin Slye)
Date of Birth: 5 November 1911 - Cincinnati, Ohio
Date of Death: 6 July 1998 - Apple Valley, California

2.  Dale Evans  (aka: Frances Octavia Smith)
Date of Birth:  31 October 1912, Uvalde, Texas
Date of Death:  7 February 2001, Apple Valley, California

Check out a new book from Empire Publishing - "THE ROY ROGERS BOOK: A REFERENCE TRIVIA SCRAPBOOK" (Paperback) --- reference trivia scrapbook of Roy Rogers written by Western film historian David Rothel whose accounts of thrilling adventures of B-Western heroes during the Saturday matinees of yesteryear takes us back to our childhood, family and friends --- this is a wish come true, reliving those wonderful years from the past through the pen of David Rothel --- Roy was a top box office draw for Republic Pictures when you went to see him on the big screen, you got exactly what the marquee said --- plenty of thrills, action and hard riding with a song or two thrown in for good measure --- Elected to the Country Music Hall of Fame in 1980 as a member of the "Sons of the Pioneers" and elected again in 1988 as Roy Rogers "King of the Cowboys" --- Roy got his horse "Trigger" in 1938 and rode him in every one of his films and TV shows after that --- "Trigger" died in 1965 age of thirty-three --- Roy's dog's name was "Bullet" and appeared in almost as many of his films as "Trigger" did --- Roy's theme song, "Happy Trails", was written by Queen of the West and his wife Dale Evans --- inducted (with his wife Dale Evans) into the "Hall of Great Western Performers of the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum" in 1976 --- inducted as a member of the "Sons of the Pioneers into the "Hall of Great Western Performers of the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum" in 1995 just three years before his death --- Don't miss this one --- now appearing on Amazon and Empire Publishing --- Don't hesitate - rush out and pick up your copy today --- Great reading in the days and weeks to come --- I guarantee it!

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc), Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") and Trevor Scott (Down Under DVD Com) as they have rekindled my interest once again for Film Noir, B-Westerns and Serials --- looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '20s, '30s & '40s and B-Westerns ... order your copy now from Amazon where there are plenty of copies available on DVD --- stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with musical adventure --- if you enjoyed this title, why not check out Amazon where they are experts in releasing B-Westerns --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 75 min on VHS/DVD ~ Republic Pictures ~ (1/01/2004)
One of the best of Roy's movies with a great musical ending, but it is the 54 minute cut version. Very good story and direction.

Visual quality of this video is fair to average. The sound track is good.  This is a 54 minute cut version of this title.  The original theatrical release had a running time of approximately 75 minutes.  Uncut versions of  this film can be found in private film collections, but none are known to  be available on home video.  This 1944 release is one of the first 3 films  Roy starred in with Dale Evans.  It is too bad that this title is not  available on video in its original full length form, as this is one of the  better Roy Rogers films.
I like Roy but the quality seems to be off it needs remastering and making it in Color

Song of Nevada, 1944 film

It begins at the Club Casanova in a big city. A couple dances. Miss Joan Farrelly sings for the audience. There is a fight. Throw him out! Jennys father questions her fiancee, then leaves for Nevada. The DC-3 airplane lands for emergency repairs. John asks some cowboys for a plate of beans for a meal. A cowboy is thrown and dragged! Roy rescues him. The cook tries to relay a message, but the rich man missed his flight. There is a song at a Medicine Show (a hidden record player). John Barrabee recognizes his horses, they were sold. That missed plan crashed, Barrabee is believed dead! His daughter sold his ranch. [A legal problem in recovery?] John wants Roy to become Jennys new boyfriend. Jenny dismisses the hired help. [Note how these cowboys are unarmed.] Roy goes to meet Jenny and shows her his contract. Roy will drive a stagecoach in a race. The rain forces a detour to the fishing shack. They will have a picnic there.

Roy suggests fishing after lunch. Then he sings with Jenny. Roy drives their stagecoach into town, and sleeps in it to guard it. A man sneaks in at night and does something to a stagecoach. The next day there is a song by an Indian princess. The race begins, six horses draw each coach. One stagecoach takes the lead, but an accident stops it! The Barrabee coach wins! There is a feast at night. Girls dance (a variation of the Can-Can?) There is a song about Jane, who visited New York city. Colonel Jack complains about the sabotage to his coach; he blames Roy! Planted evidence! Pettigrew drops by, he bought the ranch from Barrabee before John died (he says). This stops the sale of the ranch, and Rollo Bingham drops Jenny. [She is no longer wealthy.] Roy returns to tell Jenny the shocking news! Roy races to the fishing shack, but Ferguson arrived first with a gun. Roy arrives to save John. Ferguson confesses to the coach sabotage. There will be a celebration that night, with a song. Dancing girls perform. A man twirls a lasso while dancing.

This is a good story about how a family ranch is saved and a fortune hunter is rejected. It has an almost complete absence of gunplay, unusual for a Western of that era.
Best Roy Rogers and Dale Evans movie have ever seen. Loved it, never saw it before  and recommend to everyone.
Best uncut version of this movie you can buy (if you are lucky enough to find a copy).

As a child I loved Roy Rodgers.  Now I get a chance to watch them all over again.  Both my husband and I have Roy Rogers night and watch double features.  This movie was very predictable but I love that he saves the day in the end.  A great mix of cowboy and big city they are very entertaining!

As good as entertainment gets in most ways. Kids should love it as well and you can set back and relax watching something that's not going to aggravate your brain or cause more anxiety than we already have to deal with..

I'm watching the movie on TV right now.  It's one of Roy & Dale's movies I've never seen before, but I've already decided I simply must have a copy of this movie, and thank goodness Amazon has the movie for sale.  I'm getting a copy as soon as possible.  I only have one complaint, and that's that I wish someone would take these old movies and clean them up, sharpen the pictures and see what could be done to improve the sound.  It might not be possible to get them back to movie theater quality, like when they were first shown, but it would be nice if someone would try.  I'm not a purist I guess, as I would not mind seeing a colorized version of this movie either.

As for the movie itself, it has a wonderful mix of classic western songs and ones written just for this movie.  The plot is believable and the acting is up to Roy & Dale's usual high standard. Believe me, you won't be disappointed if you add this 1944 gem to your movie collection.

Roy Rogers and Dale Evans is good song of Nevada, this is black and white film. That's so beautiful place.

Jerry
